article.title: "Échelon essentiel face au sentiment d’abandon" : comment la Région
article.content:
"Échelon essentiel face au sentiment d’abandon" : comment la Région Normandie aide le territoire d’Alençon ?

Depuis 2016, la Région Normandie a investi 100 M€ sur le territoire d’Alençon, pour différents projets et dans de nombreux domaines. Tour d’horizon avec Bertrand Deniaud. 


Constructions ou rénovations, lycées, santé, transports, entreprises… En 10 ans, la Région Normandie a versé ou promis « plus de 100 M€ de fonds publics » afin de soutenir des projets sur le territoire d’Alençon et de la Communauté urbaine d’Alençon (CUA).
Si le budget régional a, comme dans l’ensemble des collectivités locales, été revu à la baisse pour 2025 (2,1 milliards d’euros, soit une diminution de 240 millions d’euros par rapport à 2024), elle « continue et continuera à soutenir les collectivités, notamment en milieu rural, où le sentiment d’abandon de la part de l’État est fort », assure Bertrand Deniaud, vice-président de la Région Normandie.
« Porter, développer ou suggérer des projets »

À mi-mandat, le président de la Région Hervé Morin a effectué une tournée des territoires normands pour rappeler cet « engagement » auprès des collectivités locales. Il était présent à Alençon à la fin du mois d’avril.

Bertrand Deniaud, d’Alençon, est l’un des huit élus de l’Orne au Conseil régional de Normandie. En détaillant les 37 projets de la Ville ou de la CUA soutenus par la Région, il souhaite mettre en avant les « résultats concrets » et rappeler que la Région est « un échelon essentiel pour les collectivités locales et pour le territoire d’Alençon ».

    La Région Normandie se veut être une collectivité d’innovation qui est là pour tout le monde. On veut être à la fois accompagnant et moteur pour porter, développer ou suggérer des projets.
    Bertrand Deniaud, vice-président de la Région Normandie

Alors qu’elles doivent se serrer la ceinture pour éponger la dette de l’État, « les communautés de communes, les villes ou les communes ne doivent pas se sentir abandonnées », milite Bertrand Deniaud, qui assure que la Région Normandie a « un niveau d’endettement contrôlable, qui doit permettre de continuer d’investir ». Le budget de la CUA devrait ainsi être amputé d’un peu plus d’1 M€ par le Gouvernement.
Centre-ville, piscine…

Pour la Ville et la Communauté urbaine d’Alençon, deux contrats de territoire, un instrument rassemblant la Région, le Département de l’Orne et la CUA pour s’entendre sur un financement commun de différents projets locaux, ont été signés depuis 2016.

Pour la période 2017-2022, la Région a apporté près de 20 % du financement total pour 30 projets identifiés, soit 6,87 M€ sur 34,80 M€.

Le plus gros investissement régional sur cette période concerne la création du pôle d’échange multimodal de la gare d’Alençon, alors que les transports ferroviaires sont l’une des compétences des Régions. La Normandie a mis 1,50 M€ sur la table, soit 50 % du coût global (3 M€).


Pour les deux phases de rénovation et de mise aux normes du centre aquatique Alencéa, la Région a pris en charge 3 M€ d’une facture particulièrement salée pour la collectivité (15,40 M€ au total).

Elle s’est aussi engagée pour l’aménagement urbain en versant 2,37 M€ pour financer 8,85 M€ de travaux, comme la requalification du centre-ville d’Alençon, l’aménagement de la place du Point-du-Jour dans le quartier de Courteille, la transformation de la cour du château des Ducs, la création de liaisons douces en périphérie d’Alençon ou encore la démolition de friches comme l’îlot Tabur et l’ancien cinéma du centre-ville.

Mi 2024, 18 des 24 projets soutenus par la Région avaient abouti ou étaient engagés, pour 6 M€ d’aides régionales (88 % du montant total prévu).

Mobilité, sport, commerce…

Pour la période 2023-2027, la Région s’est engagée à soutenir 13 projets sur 17, pour 4,72 M€ sur 24,97 M€. La Normandie prenant donc à sa charge 19 % des coûts.

Ils concernent en particulier les aménagements de voies pour la mobilité douce (piste intercommunale entre l’école de Damigny et le lycée Alain à Alençon, aménagement cyclable à Alençon et dans la zone industrielle nord à Damigny) avec 1,64 M€ de financements régionaux sur 9,75 M€ d’investissement total (17 %).

Pour favoriser l’attractivité du territoire, outre la piscine Alencéa déjà évoquée, la Région s’est engagée à participer à la transformation du bâtiment Noviciat (parc de La Providence) en tiers-lieu et pépinière d’entreprises, aux travaux de rénovation des boiseries de la médiathèque Aveline, et à l’aménagement d’un parc de loisirs à Cerisé, pour 3,06 M€ sur 15,25 M€ (20 %).

Des infrastructures sportives sont réhabilitées ou aménagées. La Région participe au financement des gymnases de Saint-Germain-du-Corbéis (850 000 € sur 4,25 M€) et du lycée Mezen (90 000 €sur 450 000 €) et à la création du terrain de football synthétique à Condé-sur-Sarthe (75 000 € sur 657 000 €).

Enfin, pour soutenir le commerce de proximité, un plan d’1,3 M€ a été mis en place. La Région participe à hauteur de 400 000 € (31 %).


Lycées et enseignement supérieur

Les lycées, compétence régionale, ont logiquement fait l’objet d’importants investissements à Alençon.

Depuis 2016, l’enveloppe régionale s’élève à 17 M€ pour quatre lycées publics et un lycée privé : lycée Alain 2,56 M€, lycée agricole d’Alençon 1,36 M€, lycée Mezen 10,54 M€, lycée Leclerc-Navarre 3,05 M€, lycée Saint-François-de-Sales (privé) 550 000 €.

Le lycée professionnel Mezen a notamment connu d’importants chantiers (extension des ateliers véhicules industriels 3,40 M€, rénovation de l’internat 2 M€) et un autre est attendu (restructuration du service de restauration 3 M€).

Pour l’enseignement supérieur, la Région a notamment versé 2,30 M€ pour le projet d’extension de Polyvia Formation, sur le campus de Damigny, inauguré en 2023, et s’apprête à mettre 18 M€ sur la table pour un important projet de mutualisation des trois CFA (3IFA, CFA Bâtiment et ETPN) et de restructuration complète du site du 3IFA, prévu pour la fin de l’année 2025. « L’objectif est de disposer de deux campus modernes pour l’apprentissage en Normandie : un au Havre et un à Alençon », explique le vice-président de la Région.
Futur hôpital, pôles de santé et formation

La santé n’est pas de sa compétence, pourtant la Région Normandie s’apprête à faire un chèque de 61,44 M€ pour construire le futur hôpital d’Alençon, dont le coût global s’élève à 154 M€. C’est autant que le financement de l’État sur ce projet. « Un tel engagement est unique en France ! », plaide Bertrand Deniaud.

Auparavant, la Région a également versé 600 000 € pour les pôles de santé de Perseigne, Saint-Germain-du-Corbéis et Alençon (Simone-Iff), qui ont coûté 4,91 M€ au total.

Un Plan régional de santé prévoit également l’amélioration des formations de santé sur le territoire. Depuis 2016, cela a notamment permis d’offrir deux nouvelles formations au sein de l’Ifres (pédicure-podologue et psychomotricien) et trois autres à l’IRFSS (éducateur spécialisé, moniteur-éducateur et ambulancier), d’ouvrir 20 places supplémentaires en formation d’aide-soignant et 8 en formation d’infirmier à l’IRFSS.

La Normandie a également financé, en 2022, quatre fauteuils en odontologie à Alençon et un chez un dentiste libéral.

« La Région oriente aussi ses investissements en fonction des problématiques propres à certains territoires et la santé en est une à Alençon », justifie Bertrand Deniaud.
Entreprises : pour l’autonomie énergétique

Enfin, la Région participe à l’aide aux entreprises du pays d’Alençon.

Depuis 2016, 88 entreprises ont perçu 3,13 M€ d’aides régionales, l’Orne représentant « le principal potentiel industriel de la région ». La production d’énergie est particulièrement concernée avec la SAS Fortin Leroy à Valframbert (430 000 €), Gaznat à Lonrai (313 000 €), Coubeyrou à Héloup (300 000 €) et l’unité de méthanisation des Cinq énergies à Gandelain (300 000 €).

L’usine de fabrication de bouchons United Caps, à Valframbert, a également bénéficié de 630 000 € en 2020, et Subteno IT à Alençon (Conseil en systèmes et logiciels informatiques) de 100 000 € lors de la crise du Covid-19.

summary:
# Résultat d’analyse

## Entités extraites
- **Langue** : fr
- **Personnes** : Bertrand Deniaud, Hervé Morin
- **Organisations** : Région Normandie, Communauté urbaine d’Alençon, CUA, Conseil régional de Normandie, Polyvia Formation, 3IFA, CFA Bâtiment, ETPN, Ifres, IRFSS, SAS Fortin Leroy, Gaznat, Coubeyrou, United Caps, Subteno IT
- **Lieux** : Normandie, Alençon, Orne, Damigny, Saint-Germain-du-Corbéis, Condé-sur-Sarthe, Cerisé, Valframbert, Lonrai, Héloup, Gandelain, Le Havre
- **Dates** : 2016, 2025, 2024, avril, 2017-2022, 2023-2027, 2023, 2022
- **Valeurs numériques** : 100 M€ (100000000.0 €), 2,1 milliards d’euros (2100000000.0 €), 240 millions d’euros (240000000.0 €), 1 M€ (1000000.0 €), 20 % (20.0 %), 6,87 M€ (6870000.0 €), 34,80 M€ (34800000.0 €), 1,50 M€ (1500000.0 €), 50 % (50.0 %), 3 M€ (3000000.0 €), 3 M€ (3000000.0 €), 15,40 M€ (15400000.0 €), 2,37 M€ (2370000.0 €), 8,85 M€ (8850000.0 €), 6 M€ (6000000.0 €), 88 % (88.0 %), 4,72 M€ (4720000.0 €), 24,97 M€ (24970000.0 €), 19 % (19.0 %), 1,64 M€ (1640000.0 €), 9,75 M€ (9750000.0 €), 17 % (17.0 %), 3,06 M€ (3060000.0 €), 15,25 M€ (15250000.0 €), 20 % (20.0 %), 850 000 € (850000.0 €), 4,25 M€ (4250000.0 €), 90 000 € (90000.0 €), 450 000 € (450000.0 €), 75 000 € (75000.0 €), 657 000 € (657000.0 €), 1,3 M€ (1300000.0 €), 400 000 € (400000.0 €), 31 % (31.0 %), 17 M€ (17000000.0 €), 2,56 M€ (2560000.0 €), 1,36 M€ (1360000.0 €), 10,54 M€ (10540000.0 €), 3,05 M€ (3050000.0 €), 550 000 € (550000.0 €), 3,40 M€ (3400000.0 €), 2 M€ (2000000.0 €), 3 M€ (3000000.0 €), 2,30 M€ (2300000.0 €), 18 M€ (18000000.0 €), 61,44 M€ (61440000.0 €), 154 M€ (154000000.0 €), 600 000 € (600000.0 €), 4,91 M€ (4910000.0 €), 20 (20.0 None), 8 (8.0 None), 88 (88.0 None), 3,13 M€ (3130000.0 €), 430 000 € (430000.0 €), 313 000 € (313000.0 €), 300 000 € (300000.0 €), 300 000 € (300000.0 €), 630 000 € (630000.0 €), 100 000 € (100000.0 €)

## Suggestions d’angles

### 1. Normandie: Investissements et impacts régionaux
Analyser comment les investissements de 100 M€ par la Région Normandie ont modifié le paysage socio-économique d'Alençon. Visualiser les effets sur l'emploi, l'éducation et l'infrastructure locale.

### 2. Transports et mobilité: un défi normand
Explorer l'impact du pôle d'échange multimodal à la gare d'Alençon sur l'amélioration des réseaux de transport. Comparer l'évolution des infrastructures de transport avant et après l'investissement régional.

### 3. Éducation et formation: un levier régional
Évaluer l'impact des 17 M€ investis dans les lycées d'Alençon sur la qualité de l'enseignement. Inclure des données sur les performances académiques et le taux de diplomation avant et après ces investissements.

### 4. Santé: Investissements régionaux inédits
Quantifier l'effet des 61,44 M€ investis par la Région dans le futur hôpital d'Alençon. Comparer le financement avec d'autres projets de santé similaires en France pour souligner l'exceptionnalité de cet engagement.

### 5. Énergies renouvelables: un pari pour l'avenir
Cartographier les investissements régionaux dans les énergies renouvelables autour d'Alençon. Analyser comment ces projets soutiennent l'autonomie énergétique et les nouvelles technologies dans la région.

angle_resources.title: Normandie: Investissements et impacts régionaux
angle_resources.description: Analyser comment les investissements de 100 M€ par la Région Normandie ont modifié le paysage socio-économique d'Alençon. Visualiser les effets sur l'emploi, l'éducation et l'infrastructure locale.

datasets.title: International investment position, portfolio and other investment in Canada, by sector, annual
datasets.description: Annual data on Canada's international investment position, detailing portfolio investment and other investment by sector. Positions are evaluated at book value.

datasets.title: International investment position, portfolio and other investment in Canada, by sector, book value, annual
datasets.description: Annual data on Canada's international investment position, detailing portfolio investment and other investment by sector. Positions are evaluated at book value.

datasets.title: DRC Health Data Ebola 2018
datasets.description:
On 1 August 2018, the Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of the Congo declared a new outbreak of Ebola virus disease in North Kivu Province. The Ministry of Health, WHO and partners are responding to this event, and working to establish the full extent of this outbreak. Numbers may fluctuate on a daily basis due to many factors, including continuing monitoring, investigation and reclassification of cases. Alert and suspected cases (not reported here), are systematically investigated to confirm or exclude Ebola virus disease before inclusion in the case counts or discarded as non-cases.

WHO GIS team is supporting the National Health Information System Division (DSNIS) to update the health related geographic data (health zones, areas and health facility structures) and other spatial information such as road, building, school together with the OpenStreetMap community and various partners. To carry out this work, the methodology was decided with local cartographers and together we were able to improve the data locally.

datasets.title: Port of Los Angeles - Historical TEU Statistics
datasets.description: Port of Los Angeles - Historical TEU Statistics: A "TEU" is a "twenty-foot equivalent unit," which is a standard measurement of shipping cargo based on a twenty-foot long shipping container.

datasets.title: City Employee Earnings
datasets.description:
__This data does not necessarily represent current salaries of employees and is intended for informational purposes only. Formal requests to document salary details or other personnel information should be made through the [City's Human Resources department](https://www.phila.gov/departments/office-of-human-resources/).__

Earnings for all City employees, including elected officials and Court staff.  Data since 2019 up to the most recent quarter of this year. Please note that since  employee counts fluctuate throughout the year, the sum  of the BASE_SALARY field does not reflect the total budgeted amount. Also, when the BASE_SALARY column is blank, it represents part-time, temporary, or seasonal employees paid by the hour. Please see [metadata](https://metadata.phila.gov/#home/datasetdetails/5543865520583086178c4ebd/representationdetails/604284dc49a209001d746460/?view_287_per_page=25&view_287_page=1) for detailed explanations of each field.

datasets.title: Electric Vehicle Population Data
datasets.description: This dataset shows the Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs) and Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEVs) that are currently registered through Washington State Department of Licensing (DOL).

datasets.title: Supply Chain Greenhouse Gas Emission Factors v1.3 by NAICS-6
datasets.description: The datasets comprise greenhouse gas (GHG) emission factors (Factors) for 1,016 U.S. commodities as defined by the 2017 version of the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). The Factors are based on GHG data for 2022. Factors are given for all NAICS-defined commodities at the 6-digit level except for electricity, government, and households. Each record consists of three factor types as in the previous releases: Supply Chain Emissions without Margins (SEF), Margins of Supply Chain Emissions (MEF), and Supply Chain Emissions with Margins (SEF+MEF). One set of Factors provides kg carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2e) per 2022 U.S. dollar (USD) for all GHGs combined using 100-yr global warming potentials from IPCC 5th report (AR5) to calculate the equivalents. In this dataset there is one SEF, MEF and SEF+MEF per commodity. The other dataset of Factors provides kg of each unique GHG emitted per 2022 dollar per commodity without the CO2e calculation. The dollar in the denominator of all factors uses purchaser prices. See the supporting file 'Aboutv1.3SupplyChainGHGEmissionFactors.docx' for complete documentation of this dataset.

datasets.title: Mode of Transportation to Work, 2001: Public Transportation (by census subdivision)
datasets.description: Nearly 74% of Canadian commuters drove to work in 2001, up from 73.3% and about 10.5% of employed Canadians used public transportation to get to work in 2001, up marginally from 10.1% in 1996. In 2001, the proportion of workers who rode to work as passengers in a car, truck or van decreased to 6.9% from 7.4% in 1996. About 6.6% of all employed Canadians walked to work in 2001, down slightly from 7.0% in 1996. The proportion of employed Canadians who cycled to work increased marginally to 1.2% in 2001 from 1.1% in 1996.

datasets.title: Mode of Transportation to Work, 2006: Public Transportation (by census division)
datasets.description: The number of people having to commute to work (usual place of work or no fixed workplace address) has risen considerably over the past five years from 13 450 900 in 2001 to 14 714 300 in 2006 or 9.4%. While the car is still the most frequently used mode of transportation for getting to work, there was a decrease in the proportion of drivers in the past five years, from 73.8% of workers in 2001 to 72.3% in 2006. In 2006, 11% of Canadian workers used public transit to get to work, compared to 10.5% in 2001 and 10.1% in 1996.

datasets.title: Transport Statistics Greater Manchester Public Transport Section
datasets.description: This report presents results of HFAS’s (Transport for Greater Manchester Highways Forecasting and Analytical Services formerly known as GMTU) public transport monitoring.  It includes trends in countywide rail and Metrolink patronage.

datasets.title: 2017-18 Harassment or Bullying Civil Rights Data Collection
datasets.description: This set of Excel files contains data on students reported as harassed or bullied or disciplined for harassment or bullying on the basis of sex, race, or disability category for all states. Each file contains three spreadsheets: total students, male students, and female students.

datasets.title: Civil Rights Data Collection (CRDC) for the 2017-18 school year
datasets.description: The Civil Rights Data Collection, 2017-18 (CRDC 2017-18) is part of the Civil Rights Data Collection (CRDC) program; program data are available beginning with the 2000 collection at https://civilrightsdata.ed.gov/data. CRDC 2017-18 is a cross-sectional survey that collects data on key education and civil rights issues in the nation's public schools, which include student enrollment and educational programs and services, disaggregated by race/ethnicity, sex, limited English proficiency, and disability. LEAs submit administrative records about schools in the district. CRDC 2017-18 is a universe survey. Key statistics produced from CRDC 2017-18 can provide information about critical civil rights issues as well as contextual information on the state of civil rights in the nation, including enrollment demographics, advanced placement, school discipline, and special education services.

datasets.title: Education
datasets.description: Contained within the 4th Edition (1974) of the Atlas of Canada is a set of four maps showing education achieved by percentage of population 5 years of age and over for each census division as of 1961. Persons classified under each of university, secondary and elementary education levels had received some formal education at these levels prior to 1961.

datasets.title: Education
datasets.description: Contained within the 3rd Edition (1957) of the Atlas of Canada is a map that shows a map of four condensed maps with proportions, medians, and institutions of education. The two upper maps indicate places in Canada where an institution of higher learning existed circa the 1958 publication date of this atlas plate. Locations where one or more degree granting universities or colleges existed (exclusive of those granting degrees in theology only) are shown. Locations where one or more other types of institutions of higher education that are affiliated with colleges, junior colleges, professional (including theological) training schools and technical institutes are indicated as well. These two maps are accompanied by a pie chart showing the percentage distribution of university and college enrolment by province for 1955 and a text listing degree granting institutions, exclusive of those granting degrees in theology only, for each province. The third map shows the proportion of the population aged five to twenty-four years attending school. The last map shows the median years of schooling for population ten years of age and over who were not attending school.

datasets.title: Sierra Nevada Landbirds Fire Analysis Monitoring Data Package, 1999-2019
datasets.description:
This dataset represents inputs for a hierarchical Bayesian model of bird population density with respect to fire history in Yosemite National Park (YOSE) and Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks (SEKI). The model uses avian point-count data, fire history data and biophysical metrics to assess localized bird population response to years-since-fire and burn severity at thousands of locations across these parks (Ray et al. 2025). Avian point-count time series were generated by The Institute for Bird Populations in collaboration with the Sierra Nevada Inventory and Monitoring Network (SIEN) of the U.S. National Park Service (Siegel & DeSante 2002, Siegel & Wilkerson 2005, Siegel et al. 2010). Fire dates and boundaries were provided by SIEN staff. Biophysical data were accessed from on-line repositories (LANDFIRE and LEMMA GNN). For more information, please refer to Ray et al. 2025.

LANDFIRE 2020. 2020. Biophysical Settings (BPS) CONUS. LANDFIRE, Earth Resources Observation and Science Center (EROS), U.S. Geological Survey. Accessed 19 May 2023, at https://www.landfire.gov/viewer/.

Ray C. 2025. SIEN birds and fire. GitHub repository, https://github.com/birdpop/firebird.

datasets.title: Current Urban Areas for Santa Fe County, New Mexico, 2006se TIGER
datasets.description:
The 2006 Second Edition TIGER/Line files are an extract of selected geographic and cartographic information from the Census TIGER database.  The geographic coverage for a single TIGER/Line file is a county or statistical equivalent entity, with the coverage area based on the latest available governmental unit boundaries. The Census TIGER database represents a seamless national file with no overlaps or gaps between parts.  However, each county-based TIGER/Line file is designed to stand alone as an independent data set or the files can be combined to cover the whole Nation.  The 2006 Second Edition  TIGER/Line files consist of line segments representing physical features and governmental and statistical boundaries.  

This shapefile represents the Current Urban Areas for Santa Fe County stored in the 2006 TIGER Second Edition dataset.

datasets.title: Physical and chemical properties of wildfire ash collected from different ecosystems and burn severities across the globe, 2003-2021
datasets.description: This dataset describes the chemical and physical properties of wildfire ash collected following wildland fires in different ecosystems and burn severity conditions across the globe. For the chemical properties, ash was collected from sampling sites across eight countries (Australia, Canada, South Africa, US, UK, The Netherlands, Spain and Austria). For the physical properties, ash was collected from four locations in Tenerife (Spain), Victoria (Australia), Manchester (UK) and Idaho (US). Full details about this dataset can be found at https://doi.org/10.5285/cd3d8b4e-0e0c-461c-8ec4-55e81d32eebb

datasets.description: This dataset shows the Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs) and Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEVs) that are currently registered through Washington State Department of Licensing (DOL).

datasets.title: NCDC Storm Events Database
datasets.description: Storm Data is provided by the National Weather Service (NWS) and contain statistics on personal injuries and damage estimates. Storm Data covers the United States of America. The data began as early as 1950 through to the present, updated monthly with up to a 120 day delay possible. NCDC Storm Event database allows users to find various types of storms recorded by county, or use other selection criteria as desired. The data contain a chronological listing, by state, of hurricanes, tornadoes, thunderstorms, hail, floods, drought conditions, lightning, high winds, snow, temperature extremes and other weather phenomena.

datasets.title: Canada - Energy
datasets.description: Contained within the 5th Edition (1978 to 1995) of the National Atlas of Canada is a plate comprised of 7 maps. The largest map shows the oil and gas fields, pipelines and processing facilities. One of two other large maps, coal and uranium, shows known and potential mining areas and existing mines for each mineral (1976); the other large map, electricity, shows electric power stations and transmission lines, and has data on potential tidal power sites (1976). Small maps show solar energy (1968), wind energy (1977), and heating degree-days (1941 to 1970 data). Flows map shows interprovincial energy flows (1974). The world map shows energy consumption for six world regions (1974). The tables give Canadian energy production and consumption (1974), historical supply and demand (1960 to 1974), and energy demand projections (1980 to 1990).

datasets.title: Consolidated Energy Statistics
datasets.description: Monthly primary and secondary energy by fuel type in terajoules (coal, natural gas, electricity, etc.) and supply and demand characteristics (production, exports, imports, etc.) for Canada.

datasets.title: DRC Health Data Ebola 2018
datasets.description:
On 1 August 2018, the Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of the Congo declared a new outbreak of Ebola virus disease in North Kivu Province. The Ministry of Health, WHO and partners are responding to this event, and working to establish the full extent of this outbreak. Numbers may fluctuate on a daily basis due to many factors, including continuing monitoring, investigation and reclassification of cases. Alert and suspected cases (not reported here), are systematically investigated to confirm or exclude Ebola virus disease before inclusion in the case counts or discarded as non-cases.

WHO GIS team is supporting the National Health Information System Division (DSNIS) to update the health related geographic data (health zones, areas and health facility structures) and other spatial information such as road, building, school together with the OpenStreetMap community and various partners. To carry out this work, the methodology was decided with local cartographers and together we were able to improve the data locally.

datasets.title: Port of Los Angeles - Historical TEU Statistics
datasets.description: Port of Los Angeles - Historical TEU Statistics: A "TEU" is a "twenty-foot equivalent unit," which is a standard measurement of shipping cargo based on a twenty-foot long shipping container.

datasets.title: City Employee Earnings
datasets.description:
__This data does not necessarily represent current salaries of employees and is intended for informational purposes only. Formal requests to document salary details or other personnel information should be made through the [City's Human Resources department](https://www.phila.gov/departments/office-of-human-resources/).__

Earnings for all City employees, including elected officials and Court staff.  Data since 2019 up to the most recent quarter of this year. Please note that since  employee counts fluctuate throughout the year, the sum  of the BASE_SALARY field does not reflect the total budgeted amount. Also, when the BASE_SALARY column is blank, it represents part-time, temporary, or seasonal employees paid by the hour. Please see [metadata](https://metadata.phila.gov/#home/datasetdetails/5543865520583086178c4ebd/representationdetails/604284dc49a209001d746460/?view_287_per_page=25&view_287_page=1) for detailed explanations of each field.

datasets.title: Supply Chain Greenhouse Gas Emission Factors v1.3 by NAICS-6
datasets.description: The datasets comprise greenhouse gas (GHG) emission factors (Factors) for 1,016 U.S. commodities as defined by the 2017 version of the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS). The Factors are based on GHG data for 2022. Factors are given for all NAICS-defined commodities at the 6-digit level except for electricity, government, and households. Each record consists of three factor types as in the previous releases: Supply Chain Emissions without Margins (SEF), Margins of Supply Chain Emissions (MEF), and Supply Chain Emissions with Margins (SEF+MEF). One set of Factors provides kg carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2e) per 2022 U.S. dollar (USD) for all GHGs combined using 100-yr global warming potentials from IPCC 5th report (AR5) to calculate the equivalents. In this dataset there is one SEF, MEF and SEF+MEF per commodity. The other dataset of Factors provides kg of each unique GHG emitted per 2022 dollar per commodity without the CO2e calculation. The dollar in the denominator of all factors uses purchaser prices. See the supporting file 'Aboutv1.3SupplyChainGHGEmissionFactors.docx' for complete documentation of this dataset.

datasets.title: Mode of Transportation to Work, 2001: Public Transportation (by census subdivision)
datasets.description: Nearly 74% of Canadian commuters drove to work in 2001, up from 73.3% and about 10.5% of employed Canadians used public transportation to get to work in 2001, up marginally from 10.1% in 1996. In 2001, the proportion of workers who rode to work as passengers in a car, truck or van decreased to 6.9% from 7.4% in 1996. About 6.6% of all employed Canadians walked to work in 2001, down slightly from 7.0% in 1996. The proportion of employed Canadians who cycled to work increased marginally to 1.2% in 2001 from 1.1% in 1996.
datasets.organisation: Natural Resources Canada | Ressources naturelles Canada

datasets.title: Mode of Transportation to Work, 2006: Public Transportation (by census division)
datasets.description: The number of people having to commute to work (usual place of work or no fixed workplace address) has risen considerably over the past five years from 13 450 900 in 2001 to 14 714 300 in 2006 or 9.4%. While the car is still the most frequently used mode of transportation for getting to work, there was a decrease in the proportion of drivers in the past five years, from 73.8% of workers in 2001 to 72.3% in 2006. In 2006, 11% of Canadian workers used public transit to get to work, compared to 10.5% in 2001 and 10.1% in 1996.
datasets.organisation: Natural Resources Canada | Ressources naturelles Canada

datasets.title: Transport Statistics Greater Manchester Public Transport Section
datasets.description: This report presents results of HFAS’s (Transport for Greater Manchester Highways Forecasting and Analytical Services formerly known as GMTU) public transport monitoring.  It includes trends in countywide rail and Metrolink patronage.

datasets.title: INSEE - Transports et déplacements
datasets.description: Data on transportation and mobility in France, including regional statistics relevant to Normandy.

datasets.description: Datasets from SNCF on train schedules, station facilities, and passenger traffic relevant to Alençon and Normandy.

datasets.title: 2017-18 Harassment or Bullying Civil Rights Data Collection
datasets.description: This set of Excel files contains data on students reported as harassed or bullied or disciplined for harassment or bullying on the basis of sex, race, or disability category for all states. Each file contains three spreadsheets: total students, male students, and female students.

datasets.title: Civil Rights Data Collection (CRDC) for the 2017-18 school year
datasets.description: The Civil Rights Data Collection, 2017-18 (CRDC 2017-18) is part of the Civil Rights Data Collection (CRDC) program; program data are available beginning with the 2000 collection at https://civilrightsdata.ed.gov/data. CRDC 2017-18 is a cross-sectional survey that collects data on key education and civil rights issues in the nation's public schools, which include student enrollment and educational programs and services, disaggregated by race/ethnicity, sex, limited English proficiency, and disability. LEAs submit administrative records about schools in the district. CRDC 2017-18 is a universe survey. Key statistics produced from CRDC 2017-18 can provide information about critical civil rights issues as well as contextual information on the state of civil rights in the nation, including enrollment demographics, advanced placement, school discipline, and special education services.

datasets.title: Education
datasets.description: Contained within the 4th Edition (1974) of the Atlas of Canada is a set of four maps showing education achieved by percentage of population 5 years of age and over for each census division as of 1961. Persons classified under each of university, secondary and elementary education levels had received some formal education at these levels prior to 1961.
datasets.organisation: Natural Resources Canada | Ressources naturelles Canada

datasets.title: Open Data Platform - Health Investments
datasets.description: Access regional health investment data, including funding for hospital projects across France.

datasets.title: Education
datasets.description: Contained within the 3rd Edition (1957) of the Atlas of Canada is a map that shows a map of four condensed maps with proportions, medians, and institutions of education. The two upper maps indicate places in Canada where an institution of higher learning existed circa the 1958 publication date of this atlas plate. Locations where one or more degree granting universities or colleges existed (exclusive of those granting degrees in theology only) are shown. Locations where one or more other types of institutions of higher education that are affiliated with colleges, junior colleges, professional (including theological) training schools and technical institutes are indicated as well. These two maps are accompanied by a pie chart showing the percentage distribution of university and college enrolment by province for 1955 and a text listing degree granting institutions, exclusive of those granting degrees in theology only, for each province. The third map shows the proportion of the population aged five to twenty-four years attending school. The last map shows the median years of schooling for population ten years of age and over who were not attending school.
datasets.organisation: Natural Resources Canada | Ressources naturelles Canada

datasets.title: Sierra Nevada Landbirds Fire Analysis Monitoring Data Package, 1999-2019
datasets.description:
This dataset represents inputs for a hierarchical Bayesian model of bird population density with respect to fire history in Yosemite National Park (YOSE) and Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks (SEKI). The model uses avian point-count data, fire history data and biophysical metrics to assess localized bird population response to years-since-fire and burn severity at thousands of locations across these parks (Ray et al. 2025). Avian point-count time series were generated by The Institute for Bird Populations in collaboration with the Sierra Nevada Inventory and Monitoring Network (SIEN) of the U.S. National Park Service (Siegel & DeSante 2002, Siegel & Wilkerson 2005, Siegel et al. 2010). Fire dates and boundaries were provided by SIEN staff. Biophysical data were accessed from on-line repositories (LANDFIRE and LEMMA GNN). For more information, please refer to Ray et al. 2025.

LANDFIRE 2020. 2020. Biophysical Settings (BPS) CONUS. LANDFIRE, Earth Resources Observation and Science Center (EROS), U.S. Geological Survey. Accessed 19 May 2023, at https://www.landfire.gov/viewer/.

Ray C. 2025. SIEN birds and fire. GitHub repository, https://github.com/birdpop/firebird.

Ray C, Siegel RB, Wilkerson RL, Schofield L, Tingley MW, Aronson S, Haultain S, Stock S, van Wagtendonk K. Fire gives avian populations a rapid and enduring boost in protected forests of California.

Siegel RB, DeSante DF. 2002. Avian inventory of Yosemite National Park (1998-2000). Report to Yosemite National Park. The Institute for Bird Populations, Point Reyes Station, CA. https://irma.nps.gov/DataStore/Reference/Profile/569146.

Siegel RB, Wilkerson RL. 2005. Landbird inventory for Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Park (2003-2004). Report to Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks. The Institute for Bird Populations, Point Reyes Station, CA. https://irma.nps.gov/DataStore/Reference/Profile/627505.

Siegel RB, Wilkerson RL, Goldin Rose M. 2010. Bird monitoring protocol for national parks in the Sierra Nevada Network. Natural Resource Report NPS/SIEN/NRR—2010/231. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado. https://irma.nps.gov/DataStore/Reference/Profile/2124954

The Census TIGER database represents a seamless national file with no overlaps or gaps between parts.  However, each county-based TIGER/Line file is designed to stand alone as an independent data set or the files can be combined to cover the whole Nation.  The 2006 Second Edition  TIGER/Line files consist of line segments representing physical features and governmental and statistical boundaries.
